channel.title: The Institute on Man and Science
channel.description:
A lecture and discussion series on major current problems like urban decay; pollution; space exploration; and the role of science in finding solutions. Talks were held during the summer of 1968 at the Institute on Man and Science, New York.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

image.title: The Institute on Man and Science

item.title: Our world situation
item.description: This program presents the keynote address given by Paul Martin.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.title: Philosophies Molding Chinese Life
item.description: A speech by Ch'u Chai, professor of Chinese culture at New York's New School for Social Research, on the connection between philosophy and the Chinese way of life.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: Philosophy & Ethics

item.title: Concert of cultures
item.description: This program features the lecture "The Concert of Cultures" by W. Warren Wagar.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.title: Can Man Manage the City?
item.description: This program features the lecture "Can Man Manage the City?" by Timothy Costello, Deputy Mayor-City Admnistrator of the City of New York.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.title: The Book in China
item.description: The Book in China. L. Carrington Goodrich, a research professor in Chinese history at Columbia University, explores the development of books in China starting, starting with wood block printing somewhere after the year 700.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: Technology

item.title: Change and Continuity in Modern China
item.description: Ch'u Chai, professor of Chinese culture at New York's New School for Social Research, discussed the massive changes in China since 1919's May Fourth Movement and the beginnings of the Chinese Communist Party.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Man is the System
item.description: Hudson Hoagland, president of the Worcester Foundation, describes how the stresses of overpopulation and competition lead to physical and psychological problems in both animal and human societies.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: Sociology

item.title: Crime, revolution and Black Power
item.description: This program features the lecture "Crime, Revolution and Black Power" by Wyatt Tee Walker, Special Assistant to Governor Nelson Rockefeller on Urban Affairs, Pastor Canaan Baptist Church, Harlem, was Executive Director, Southern Christian Leadership Conference.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.title: China in the World Drama
item.description: Dr. William Hung, research professor at the Harvard-Yenching Institute, speaks of China's role in world drama, which he describes as a mingling of conflict and assimilation among nations, races, religions, and cultures.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Cosmos and Man
item.description: Albert G. Wilson, an astrophysicist working at Douglas Aircraft, describes the importance of finding meaning, not only as members of society but as members of the cosmos, at a time when economic and social trends are robbing individuals of their role in society.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: Sociology

item.title: Response to keynote address
item.description: This program presents the response to the keynote address given by Paul Martin. Responses are given by Albert Wilson, astrophysicist, Douglas Aircraft; and Harold Williams, United States Army, assigned to urban civil disturbances.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.title: China Contributions to Science
item.description: T.C. Chou of Michigan Technological University discusses Chinese contributions to science, explaining that such developments as arched bridges, water wheels, and submarines are only the tip of the iceberg of Chinese historical innovations.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: Technology

item.title: China Contributions to World Culture
item.description: L. Carrington Goodrich, research professor in Chinese history, Columbia University, describes a number of Eastern Asia's contributions to the modern world.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: Technology

item.title: The Meaning of Life
item.description: Dr. Eric Steinthal of Newburgh, New York, offers a series of psychological, philosophical, and religious perspectives on the age-old question, "What is the meaning of life?"
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: Religion

item.title: City of Man in historical perspective
item.description: This program features the lecture "The City of Man in Historical Perspective" by W. Warren Wagar, Professor of History, University of New Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.title: Systems Interact, part III
item.description: Systems Interact: What systems analysis has taught us about ourselves and the natural world, Part I. V.L. Parsegian, physicist at the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, describes the importance of studying the cycles regulating natural phenomena, including long chains of effects both preceding and following them.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: Science & Technology

item.title: Necessity: The Mother of Chaos
item.description: Yale University ecologist Paul B. Sears describes the social, economic, and environmental disruption caused by two offspring of necessity, otherwise known as the mother of invention: military necessity and economic necessity.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: Sociology

item.title: Systems Interact, part I
item.description: Systems Interact: What systems analysis has taught us about ourselves and the natural world, Part I. V.L. Parsegian, physicist at the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, describes the importance of studying the cycles regulating natural phenomena, including long chains of effects both preceding and following them.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: Science & Technology

item.title: Probing Space
item.description: A speech by Curtis Hemenway, director of the Dudley Observatory, who makes the case for continued funding for space science, including examples of how related advances in communications, meteorology, and geology have already benefited the American people.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: Space sciences--United States

item.title: Understanding Media
item.description: Gordon Martin of the National Film Board of Canada stresses the importance of studying and understanding our current media environment in order to avoid forms of manipulation such as advertising.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: Television

item.title: Understanding China
item.description: Understanding China. Dr. Paul Chih Meng, director emeritus of the China Institute in America, stresses the importance of scientists attaining a basic understanding of China, particularly in light of that country's development of nuclear weapons.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: United States Policy in East Asia
item.description: The Hon. Everett F. Drumright, former U.S. ambassador to the Republic of China, from 1958-1962, discusses the evolution and limitations of the United States' policy towards China, which arose from the desire to prevent that country from being dominated by any foreign power.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: World War, 1939-1945

item.title: A Cosmopolitan Morality
item.description: Historian and futurist W. Warren Wager presents an outline of a future cosmopolitan society based on a combination of ethics and scientific advances.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: Sociology

item.title: Systems Interact, part II
item.description: Systems Interact: What systems analysis has taught us about ourselves and the natural world, Part I. V.L. Parsegian, physicist at the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, describes the importance of studying the cycles regulating natural phenomena, including long chains of effects both preceding and following them.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: Science & Technology

item.title: Role of the urban coalition
item.description: This program features the lecture "The Role of the Urban Coalition" by Christian A. Herter, Jr., Vice President, Mobil Oil Company and Chairman, New York Urban Coalition.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.title: Chinese People in the United States
item.description: Betty Lee Sung, author of The Mountain of Gold, describes the experiences of Chinese Americans, whose history and contributions have largely been ignored.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: United States--Emigration and immigration--History--20th century

item.title: From Particles to Systems and Patterns in Science
item.description: Eugene McLaren, Science and Mathematics chairman, State University of New York at Albany, describes the most complex system we must study today: the system of mankind in his scientific world, which represents the magnitude and the widespread effects of human activity that have been made possible by scientific knowledge.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: Science & Technology

item.title: Cities and the suburbs
item.description: This program presents the lecture "The Cities and the Suburbs" by Irving M. Levine, Director, Education and Urban Planning Department, American Jewish Committee.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.title: Creating a Climate and Building Bridges
item.description: In this speech, Dr. Paul Chih Meng, director emeritus of the China Institute in America, assesses the prospects for communication between the United States and China given the stark political and cultural differences between the two nations.
item.dc:creator: Institute on Man and Science
item.dc:subject: World Politics
